Title: Armor
Excerpt: An additional number displayed next to a unit’s power number. Whenever damage is dealt to an armored unit, it is first subtracted from the armor count and then any excess is then subtracted from that unit’s power...
Description:
An additional number displayed next to a unit’s power number.

Whenever damage is dealt to an armored unit, it is first subtracted from the armor count and then any excess damage is subtracted from that unit’s power.

Title: Tall punish
Excerpt: A term that describes cards that punish either investing too many points into one unit or just playing very high power units...
Description: A term that describes cards that punish either investing too many points into one unit or just playing very high power units. Opposite of wide punish. Example: Geralt of Rivia, Leo Bonhart, Vilgefortz, Bloody Baron.

Title: Archetype
Excerpt: A classification of decks usually based on either the speed at which they play out or in games that do not employ “Mana” as a resource (such as Gwent), the style in which a deck plays out...
Description:
A classification of decks usually based on either the speed at which they play out or in games that do not employ “Mana” as a resource (such as Gwent), the style in which a deck plays out.

Archetypes in Gwent include but are not necessarily limited to:
  • Swarm
  • Hyperthin
  • Midrange
  • Control
  • No-unit
  • Point-slam
  • Engine overload
Do keep in mind, however, that most of these definitions are pretty loose and most of the decks are usually a combination of several archetypes rather than falling exclusively into one.

Title: Swarm
Excerpt: A deck that generates a massive number of (usually) small tokens and then using swarm pay-off cards to win the game...
Description: A deck archetype that generates a massive number of (usually) small tokens and then using swarm pay-off cards to win the game. An example of such a deck would be the “Elf Swarm” deck. This deck tends to fill the board with elves to eventually take advantage of its pay-off cards such as “The Great Oak” or “Isengrim Faoiltiarna” that gain more value as you swarm the board.

Title: Control
Excerpt: Same as Midrange but with more focus on removal and disrupting your opponent’s game plan rather than putting points on the board...
Description: A deck archetype that is the same as Midrange but with more focus on removal and disrupting your opponent’s game plan rather than putting points on the board.

Title: Wild Boar of the Sea
Description: Wild Boar of the Sea Machine, Ship Deploy (Melee): Damage all damaged enemy units by 1, then damage all enemy units by 1.

Title: Hyperthin
Excerpt: A deck archetype that tries to thin to a very small number of cards so that you can control precisely what you have left in your deck in order to play your hyperthin pay-off cards without their potential drawbacks...
Description: A deck archetype that tries to thin to a very small number of cards so that you can control precisely what you have left in your deck in order to play your hyperthin pay-off cards without their potential drawbacks. For instance, a Nilfgaard Hyperthin deck strives to thin the deck to the point where it has only 2 (or occasionally 1) high power units left in the deck. By doing so it ensures that cards like “Yennefer: Divination”, “Triss Merigold”, “Vilgefortz” and “Xarthisius” gain insane amounts of value to close out the round.

Title: Midrange
Excerpt: A deck archetype that has a healthy combination of Control cards (cards that remove a threat from your opponent’s side) and high-value cards...
Description: A deck archetype that has a healthy combination of Control cards (cards that remove a threat from your opponent’s side) and high-value cards. An example of such a deck would be Arachas Swarm Organics that has a good number of high-value plays in “Yghern”, “Golyat” and the like combined with a plethora of removal options such as “Parasite” or “Hideous Feast”.

Title: No-unit
Excerpt: A very infamous category of control decks that play tends to not play many units and thereby denying a lot of value on the cards that interact with the opposing board by any means. No example given for obvious reasons.
Description: A very infamous category of control decks that tends to not play many units and thereby denying a lot of value on the cards that interact with the opposing board by any means. No example given for obvious reasons.

Title: Point-slam
Excerpt: An archetype of decks that revolve around putting a lot of points on the board with little to no regard to what your opponent is playing...
Description: An archetype of decks (or just playstyle) that revolves around putting a lot of points on the board with little to no regard to what your opponent is playing. An example of such a deck would be the Skellige Scenario deck or any deck that uses Fruits of Ysgith as the leader ability. The former includes a very low number of removal options and usually wins through playing engines that gain massive amounts of value per turn.

Title: Engine overload
Excerpt: A type of deck that plays an enormous number of engine units to overwhelm the opponent as they likely will not be able to answer all of them.
Description: A deck archetype that plays an enormous number of engine units to overwhelm the opponent, as they will not be able to effectively answer all of them.

Title: AQ
Excerpt: Short for “Arachas Queen”. This refers to the “Arachas Swarm” leader ability.
Description: Short for “Arachas Queen”. This refers to the “Arachas Swarm” leader ability.

Title: Baiting
Excerpt: Deceiving an opponent into playing in a certain way, be it committing a certain card, playing slowly or aggressively...
Description:
Deceiving an opponent into playing in a certain way, be it committing a certain card, playing too slowly or aggressively.

Example: You are about to play a unit with 5 power that is going to gain a tremendous amount of value if it lives until the next turn. However, you know (or suspect) that your opponent may have a copy of Alzurs Thunder in their deck that can deal 5 damage to any unit, thereby capable of killing your 5 power unit after you play it.

To play around this, you can throw another target at your opponent for them to use their Alzurs Thunder on, essentially sacrificing it so that your power play goes through. In this scenario, you are trying to bait your opponent’s removal card.

Title: Bleeding
Excerpt: Opposite of dry-passing, refers to the act of playing deeper into a round with the intent of stripping your opponent of one (or more) of their power plays (win conditions) or otherwise, with the intent of simply shortening the following rounds so that certain cards on the opposing side play for less value...
Description: Opposite of dry-passing, refers to the act of playing deeper into a round with the intent of stripping your opponent of one (or more) of their power plays (win conditions) or otherwise, with the intent of simply shortening the following rounds so that certain cards on the opposing side play for less value. Be advised however that this strategy takes practice to master and can backfire extremely hard if done without moderation. The strategy is usually employed in the second round by the player who has won the first round, but it can refer to playing deep into the first round with the intention of blocking your opponent from bleeding you in the second round. Moreover, bleeding can occur in Round 1, in which case it means playing as deep as possible into the round while maintaining reach, potentially trading-up with the opponent and forcing out their gold cards. This can be especially effective if you know that their game plan relies on winning the first round. Example: Assume you are playing against a deck that you know has two significant win conditions. You managed to win the first round, but you know that you cannot win another round unless you strip the opponent off of at least one of their win conditions. Therefore, you play into the second round with the intention of forcing your opponent to commit one of their power plays, weakening their following round significantly so that you have a way better shot at winning the game.

Title: Blue Coin
Excerpt: Refers to being the first person to act when the match starts...
Description: Refers to being the first person to act when the match starts. During the beta phase of the game, acting first or second was respectively signified with a blue or a red coin, hence the expression.

Title: BM
Excerpt: Bad Manners...
Description: Bad Manners. A term used to describe intentionally obnoxious behavior for various reasons including but not limited to frustrating and irritating the opponent, gloating or simply dragging the game out as to inconvenience the opponent. Usually enacted through playing deliberately slowly (even if the play is obvious), intentionally playing suboptimally to humiliate the opponent, or emoting excessively.

Title: Card Advantage
Excerpt: Refers to having more cards in hand than your opponent at the start of a round...
Description: Refers to having more cards in hand than your opponent at the start of a round. Card advantage is extremely valuable in Gwent for a variety of reasons and in some cases, equals an uncontested victory.

Title: Carryover
Excerpt: Any form of value for subsequent rounds...
Description: Any form of value for subsequent rounds. Example 1: If any unit with the “Resilience” tag survives the round in which it was played (such as Vandergrift for example) it will have generated carryover points into the next round. Example 2: Suppose you play Naglfar in the second round. Naglfar shows you two random gold cards, you get to play one and the next one is put on top of your deck. Therefore, you will have created carryover for the following round by playing Naglfar because you put a gold card on top of your deck. Example 3: You have Hawker Smuggler in play, boosting a random unit in your hand at the end of each turn. As long as you don’t play the boosted units, those boosts will count as carryover, as you can spend them in subsequent rounds.

Title: Coin-flip Abuse
Excerpt: See “Red Coin Abuse”.
Description: See “Red Coin Abuse”.

Title: Consistency
Excerpt: How well a deck can repeatedly execute its game plan.
Description: How well a deck can repeatedly execute its game plan.

Title: Dry-pass
Excerpt: Opposite of bleeding, a term that describes passing a round (usually the second round) without playing any cards...
Description:
The opposite of bleeding, dry-pass is a term that describes passing a round (usually the second round) without playing any cards. The act of dry-passing can only be done by the player who won the first round. The reasons for dry-passing include but are not limited to:
  • Hand quality not being good enough to efficiently execute a bleed and therefore you would be forced to pass or risk giving your opponent card advantage.
  • Round is too short for a bleed to be viable without losing a card.
  • Your long round is considerably better than your opponents so you gain nothing by actually attempting to bleed.
Variations: Dry pass, dry passing, dry-passing, dry passes, dry-passes, dry passed, dry-passed

Title: Engine
Excerpt: Any card that generates value over time...
Description: Any card that generates value over time. Examples: Any card with the “Thrive” tag is considered an engine as they will get buffed whenever you play another unit that is greater than their current power. “Reinforced Trebuchet” is an engine because at the end of each turn it deals 1 damage to a unit on the Ranged row thereby generating 1 point per turn.

Title: Elder Bears
Excerpt: A gwent slang term referring mostly to the cards “Damien de la Tour” and “Steffan Skellen” (or any expensive Order card) that will effectively play as an overpriced “Elder Bear” card if shut down.
Description: A Gwent slang term referring mostly to the cards “Damien de la Tour” and “Stefan Skellen” (or any expensive Order card) that will effectively play as an overpriced “Elder Bear” card if shut down.

Title: First say
Excerpt: Acting first in the second or the third round. Not to be confused with Blue Coin.
Description: Acting first in the second or the third round. Not to be confused with Blue Coin.

Title: Finisher
Excerpt: Refers to the final play of each side which is usually expected to be a massive point swing...
Description: Refers to the final play of each side which is usually expected to be a massive point swing. Also, see “Win Condition”.

Title: fMMR
Excerpt: Short for “faction MatchMaking Rating”. See “MMR” for more details.
Description: Short for “faction MatchMaking Rating”. See “MMR” for more details.

Title: GG (WP)
Excerpt: Short for “Good Game (Well Played)”...
Description: Short for “Good Game (Well Played)”.  After a game ends there’s a “GG” button in the post-match screen that sends your opponent a smattering amount of resources as appreciation for the game you just played.

Title: Greedy
Excerpt: An adjective used to describe a deck that relies heavily on either drawing the correct cards in the correct rounds, having some key cards stick to the board with little protection, or high-rolling off of random-based cards to win the game.
Description: An adjective used to describe a deck that relies heavily on either drawing the correct cards in the correct rounds, having some key cards stick to the board with little protection, or high-rolling off of random-based cards to win the game.

Title: High-roll
Excerpt: Opposite of low-roll. A term used to describe one of the better outcomes of a random event in the game...
Description: Opposite of low-roll. A term used to describe one of the better outcomes of a random event in the game. Example: Suppose you play the “Bribery” card which offers a random choice of 3 cards (including bronzes) from your opponent’s deck for you to pick and play one. Now if you get an extremely valuable gold card in the choice of 3 cards, you will have high-rolled.
Variations: High roll, high rolls, high-rolling, high rolling

Title: Ladder
Excerpt: Ranked play.
Description: Ranked play.

Title: Last say
Excerpt: Acting last in the third round. Not to be confused with Red Coin.
Description: Acting last in the third round. Not to be confused with Red Coin. Last say can be especially valuable for the decks that want to play a massive finisher without having to give their opponents a chance to react to it.

Title: List
Excerpt: A deck.
Description: A deck.

Title: Low-roll
Excerpt: Opposite of high-roll. A term used to describe a worse than expected outcome in the resolution of a random event in the game...
Description: Opposite of high-roll. A term used to describe a worse than expected outcome in the resolution of a random event in the game. Example: Imagine you play a Delirium card that deals 6 damage randomly split between all enemies on an enemy row. There are 8 units on that row. Assume that your preferred outcome is that you hit 6 distinct units. If you hit one single unit out of 8, 6 times back to back, you will have low-rolled.

Title: Matchup
Excerpt: How well a deck performs against another one...
Description: How well a deck performs against another one. Example: The ‘X’ matchup for the deck ‘Y’ is pretty favorable.
Variations: Match up, Match-up, Matchups, Match ups, Match-ups

Title: Meta
Excerpt: A term that describes something that is effective or prevalent at the time...
Description: A term that describes something that is effective or prevalent at the time. Example: A meta deck, a meta card.

Title: Mill (Archetype)
Excerpt: A rare (and often regarded as obnoxious) archetype of decks (which is almost exclusive to Nilfgaard in Gwent) that revolves around forcing the opponent’s cards out of their deck by any means possible so that they will have no cards left in their deck by the start of the third round...
Description: A rare (and often regarded as obnoxious) archetype of decks (which is almost exclusive to Nilfgaard in Gwent) that revolves around forcing the opponent’s cards out of their deck by any means possible so that they will have no cards left in their deck by the start of the third round so that some cards with drawbacks tied to your opponents deck (such as "Vilgefortz" or "Tibor Eggebracht") can be played for full value. Also see "Mill".
Variations: Milling your opponent, Mills your opponent, mill your opponent, milled your opponent

Title: Mill
Excerpt: Trading a card in your collection for resources...
Description: Trading a card in your collection for resources. Also see "Mill (Archetype)".

Title: Mirror
Excerpt: The matchup of a deck against itself.
Description: The matchup of a deck against itself.

Title: MMR
Excerpt: Short for “MatchMaking Rating”. Your place on the leaderboards is decided by your MMR. Your MMR is the combined score of your 4 highest fMMRs...
Description: Short for “MatchMaking Rating”. Your place on the leaderboards is decided by your MMR. Your MMR is the combined score of your 4 highest fMMRs. For more information refer to the in-game legacy or our Ranked mode guide.

Title: MO
Excerpt: Short for “Monsters”.
Description: Short for “Monsters”.

Title: Mulligan
Excerpt: The act of replacing some of the cards in your hand with fresh draws from the deck and then shuffling the old cards back into the deck...
Description: The act of replacing some of the cards in your hand with fresh draws from the deck and then shuffling the old cards back into the deck. Mulligans do not have to be necessarily taken. Usually done when your current hand quality is not satisfactory and you’re hoping to draw better cards.

Title: Netdecking
Excerpt: Copying decks from the internet rather than making them yourself. Speaking of which, make sure to check out our newest meta report!
Description: Copying decks from the internet rather than making them yourself. Speaking of which, make sure to check out our newest meta report!

Title: NG
Excerpt: Short for “Nilfgaard”.
Description: Short for “Nilfgaard”.

Title: NR
Excerpt: Short for “Northern Realms”.
Description: Short for “Northern Realms”.

Title: OP
Excerpt: Short for “Overpowered”. A term loosely attributed to decks (or factions) that feel unfair to play against because they are seemingly much better than everything else.
Description: Short for “Overpowered”. A term loosely attributed to decks (or factions) that feel unfair to play against because they are seemingly much better than everything else.

Title: Package
Excerpt: A package refers to several cards that serve a particular purpose which is included in a deck to further assist that deck with executing its game plan...
Description: (of cards) A package refers to several cards that serve a particular purpose which is included in a deck to further assist that deck with executing its game plan. Example: A “Poison Package” contains a couple of cards that can apply the “Poison” status to a unit. This package can come in handy in the ‘X’ deck.

Title: Pile
Excerpt: A slang term loosely attributed to a (bad) deck.
Description: A slang term loosely attributed to a (bad) deck.

Title: Proc
Excerpt: A term used to describe when an effect is triggered, be it randomly or when a certain condition is met...
Description: A term used to describe when an effect is triggered, be it randomly or when a certain condition is met. Example: Proccing a Scenario card would mean progressing it to the next chapter. Example 2: If you have four 1-power units on board with the “Thrive” tag and you now play a unit with, say, 3 power, you will proc the “Thrive” on all four of those 1-power units.

Title: Reach
Excerpt: To have the reach in a round is to have the ability to catch up with the current point difference between two sides without giving your opponent card advantage.
Description: To have the reach in a round is to have the ability to catch up with the current point difference between two sides without giving your opponent card advantage.

Title: Red Coin
Excerpt: Refers to being the second person to act when the match starts...
Description: Refers to being the second person to act when the match starts. During the beta phase of the game, acting first or second was respectively signified with a blue or a red coin, hence the expression.

Title: Red Coin Abuse
Excerpt: A term that refers to playing extremely high tempo on Red Coin with the intent of winning on even. Otherwise could refer to looking to play weaker cards while still threatening to win the round with enough reach or forcing the opponent to trade-down with their good cards.
Description: A term that refers to playing extremely high tempo on Red Coin with the intent of winning on even. Otherwise refers to playing your weak cards, while still threatening to win the round with enough reach, or forcing the opponent to trade-down with their good cards.
Variations: Coin Abuse, Abusing Coin-flip, Abusing Coin Flip, Abusing Red Coin

Title: RNG
Excerpt: Short for “Random Number Generator” but usually describes any random event or its resolution in the game. It can also be loosely translated into “luck” depending on the context...
Description: Short for “Random Number Generator” but usually describes any random event or its resolution in the game. It can also be loosely translated into “luck” depending on the context. Example: Good/Bad RNG means Good/Bad luck.

Title: Roping
Excerpt: Playing slowly every turn to the point where an indicator is shown to remind you of the remaining time.
Description: Playing slowly every turn to the point where an indicator is shown to remind you of the remaining time.

Title: Round Control
Excerpt: Having control over the length of the final round...
Description: Having control over the length of the final round. Whichever player wins the first round gains “Round Control”, i.e, they can dictate whether the final round is going to be as long as, or as short as possible by deciding whether or not they want to dry-pass or bleed in the second round.

Title: Row punish
Excerpt: A term that describes cards that punish row-stacking...
Description: A term that describes cards that punish row-stacking. Example: Geralt: Igni or Geralt: Yrden, Lacerate, Surrender, Hemdall.

Title: Row-stacking
Excerpt: Playing a lot of units on the same row...
Description: Playing a lot of units on the same row. Bad against row punish and good for row pay-off cards (see “Yaevinn” or “The Great Oak” for example). Row-stacking is generally not advised if you gain nothing by doing it.

Title: SK
Excerpt: Short for “Skellige”.
Description: Short for “Skellige”.

Title: ST
Excerpt: Short for “Scoia’tael”.
Description: Short for “Scoia’tael”.

Title: Stay Ahead (Tempo Out)
Excerpt: A term that means being able to stay ahead in points while having as many cards as your opponent...
Description: A term that means being able to stay ahead in points while having as many cards as your opponent. Usually relevant in the first and the second rounds. Example: Suppose you are behind 7 points right now. Your opponent has 5 cards and you have 6. If you play a card that results in a swing of 8 or more points, you will have tempo-ed out/stayed ahead.

Title: SY
Excerpt: Short for “Syndicate”.
Description: Short for “Syndicate”.

Title: Synergy
Excerpt: How well two (or more) cards work together in cohesion...
Description: How well two (or more) cards work together in cohesion. A deck is generally considered good if it contains good synergy between its cards. Example: “Anna Strenger” has a very strong synergy with “Tridam Infantry”.

Title: Tempo
Excerpt: The pace at which a play is made...
Description: The pace at which a play is made. A high tempo play is a play that results in a massive point swing while a low tempo play is a slow play. Otherwise, this term can also be loosely translated into “points”. Also, see “Stay Ahead (Tempo Out)”. Example: If someone were to say “this card is worth a lot of tempo” that would mean “this card is worth a lot of points” or "this card has a lot of value".

Title: Tech (Choice)
Excerpt: A tech card (tech choice) is a card that doesn’t necessarily synergize with the rest of the cards in the deck and is merely there because you want to target a specific card (or type of cards) in more prevalent decks thereby giving you an extra edge over decks without that tech...
Description: A tech card (tech choice) is a card that doesn’t necessarily synergize with the rest of the cards in the deck and is merely there because you want to target a specific card (or type of cards) in more prevalent decks thereby giving you an extra edge over decks without that tech. Example: In a meta where a specific type of cards, say artifacts for example, are extremely prevalent, one might be incentivized to play a 1-of copy of the "Bomb Heaver" card just to gain an extra edge when going toe to toe against decks that play high-value artifacts. Despite "Bomb Heaver" not necessarily having any synergy with the rest of the deck.
Variations: Tech, Tech Card, Tech Choice, Teched, Teching

Title: Thinning
Excerpt: Refers to the act of drawing cards from your deck and thereby “thinning” it so that it contains fewer cards than it used to...
Description: Refers to the act of drawing cards from your deck and thereby “thinning” it so that it contains fewer cards than it used to. A deck that contains a lot of thinning is considered to be consistent, as you will have a much higher chance of drawing your win conditions if the remainder of your deck contains fewer cards.

Title: Token
Excerpt: A unit (or special) that is generated from another card...
Description: An uncollectible unit (or special) that comes into play through another card. Example: “Plague Maiden” is a card that generates seven 1-power tokens on Deathwish. “Half-elf Hunter” is another card that generates a 3-power token when played.

Title: Top-deck
Excerpt: A term used to talk about what is on top of one’s deck...
Description: A term used to talk about what is on top of one’s deck. Example: If you draw the card ‘X’ at the start of the third round, you will have “top-decked” that card.

Title: Trade-down (or up)
Excerpt: A term that describes an unfavorable (favorable) exchange between the cards with their potential values in mind...
Description: A term describing an unfavorable (or favorable) exchange between two cards with their potential values in mind. Example: If your “Damien de la Tour” dies to an “Alzurs Thunder” you will have severely traded-down, as you paid 11 provisions only to put 5 points on the board. And vice versa, your opponent will have traded-up in this situation.
Variations: Trade-down, Trade Down, Trading-down, Trade-up, Trade Up, Trading-up

Title: Tutor
Excerpt: Refers to a type of cards whose purpose is playing other (usually more valuable) cards from your deck...
Description: Refers to a type of cards whose purpose is playing other (usually more valuable) cards from your deck. Tutors provide consistency by thinning your deck as well as sometimes giving you direct access to your win conditions. Bricking can often happen with this type of card.  Example: “Fauve” is a tutor card because it can play any card with the “Nature” tag from your deck. So if you play, for example, “Nature’s Rebuke” through your Fauve, you will have tutored your Nature’s Rebuke with Fauve. Example 2: “Royal Decree” is another tutor card that gives you access to any unit from your remaining deck.

Title: Wide punish
Excerpt: A term that describes cards that punish investing points into many different units...
Description: A term that describes cards that punish investing points into many different units. Opposite of tall punish. Examples: Lacerate, Tinboy, Surrender, Wild Boar of the Sea.

Title: Win Condition
Excerpt: Refers to what your game plan on a deck ultimately should lead up to in order for you to close out a game. A win condition usually describes a card (or a set of cards) off of whom you expect to win the game...
Description:
Refers to what your game plan should ultimately lead up to in order for you to close out a game. A win condition usually describes a card (or a set of cards) off of whom you expect to win the game.

Example: If the “Scorch” card is a win condition in your deck, then you’re hoping to win the game through setting up a number of the enemy units so that they’re all the highest power on the board and then playing your Scorch card.

Title: Win (Lose) On Even
Excerpt: A phrase that describes a situation where either side is in a winning position but both sides have the same number of cards (even cards)...
Description: A phrase that describes a situation where either side is in a winning position but both sides have the same number of cards (even cards). For instance, if you win the first round on even at 7 cards, that would mean that you have won the round but you and your opponent both have 7 cards left in your hands. Losing on even is a particularly perilous situation as it either gives your opponent the option to dry-pass, effectively forcing you to lose card advantage or freely bleed you in the second round without having to worry about losing card advantage themselves.
Variations: Winning On Even, Win On Even, Losing On Even, Lose On Even

Excerpt: Read two-oh) After having won the first round, playing into the second round with the intention of winning the game, (potentially) despite having one less card in hand than your opponent. Not to be confused with bleeding.
Description: (Read two-oh) After having won the first round, playing into the second round with the intention of winning the game, (potentially) despite having one less card in hand than your opponent. Not to be confused with bleeding.

Title: Collusion
Description: Collusion Crime If you control a unit with the gang category: Blindeyes - Increase all other effects by 1. Crownsplitters - Boost an allied unit with the lowest power by 4. Cutups - Damage an enemy unit with the highest power by 4. Firesworn - Spawn 2 Firesworn Zealot in a random allied row. Tidecloaks - Gain 4 Coins.

Title: Brick
Excerpt: Used to describe a card that due to the current state of the game, be it your hand, either graveyards,either decks or either sides of the board, will inevitably play for much less value than originally intended...
Description:
Used to describe a card that due to the current state of the game, be it your hand, either graveyards,either decks or either sides of the board, will inevitably play for much less value than originally intended.

Example: Suppose you have a Fauve card in your hand at the moment. Fauve is a card that plays any card with the “Nature” tag from your deck. However, at the moment, you have all of your Nature cards in your hand so once you play Fauve it cannot play anything from your deck. Here in this example, you will have bricked your Fauve (or your Fauve is a brick).

Description: Regis: Higher Vampire Vampire Order (Melee): Drain an enemy by the amount of boost it has.

Description: Triss Merigold Human, Mage Deploy (Ranged): Reveal a random unit from your deck and damage an enemy unit by its power.

Description: Yennefer of Vengerberg Human, Mage Deploy (Melee): Damage all other units by 2. Deploy (Ranged): Boost all other units by 2.

Description: Geralt: Aard Witcher Deploy (Melee): Damage 3 enemy units by 2, then move them to the ranged row.

Title: Yennefer: Conjurer
Description: Yennefer: Conjurer Human, Mage Order: Damage the highest enemy unit(s) by 1. Cooldown: 1.

Title: Dudu

Title: Proactive
Excerpt: (of a play or a card) that doesn't require any interaction with your opponent in any way in order to generate full value...
Description:
(of a play or a card) that doesn't require any interaction with the current game state in any way in order to generate full value. Opposite of reactive.

Example: If every card in your hand deals damage when played and your opponent doesn't have any units on their side of the board, you would say you lack proactivity, or that you do not have a proactive play. In the same situation, a card that doesn't interact with your opponent and has full value on its own, such as "Yghern" for instance, would be a proactive card/play.

Title: Reactive
Excerpt: (of a card or play) that directly interacts with the current game state in some way in order to play for full value...
Description:
(of a card or play) that directly interacts with the current game state in some way in order to play for full value. Opposite of proactive.

Examples: Any card that deals damage to an enemy unit such as "Alzurs Thunder". Any card that destroys or banishes an enemy unit such as "Imleriths Wrath". "Vrihedd Officer" can also be considered reactive as it requires on a unit to be present on either side of the board to play for full value.

Certain cards can interact with either graveyard. Note: If a card is banished or has the Doomed status when it dies it will be completely removed from the game for the duration of it and will not appear in the graveyard.

Cards that interact with the opponent's graveyard in order to hinder their gameplan are referred to as "Graveyard Hate".

Example: Xavier Lemmens. Assire var Anahid.

Title: Ceiling and Floor
Excerpt: The ceiling on a card is the maximum possible amount of points that card play for. The floor on a card, on the other hand, is the minimum amount of points that card can play for...
Description:
The ceiling on a card is the maximum possible amount of points that card play for. The floor on a card, on the other hand, is the minimum amount of points that card can play for.

Example: The ceiling on Philippa Eilhart is 21 points (3 point body, deny 9 from enemy and add 9 to your side). The floor on Bloody Baron is 7 points (if you play him on Ranged row assuming you have nothing to reset).

Title: Develop
Excerpt: To set up...
Description:
To set-up.

Example: To develop your graveyard means to play units in earlier rounds in order to set-up your cards that interact with your graveyard. For instance, playing "Yghern" in Round 1 so that you have good "Ozzrel" value in the subsequent rounds.

Title: Initiative
Excerpt: Trigger ability if using this card is the first action during your turn...
Description: Trigger ability if using this card is the first action during your turn. Initiative does NOT trigger if you have taken any other action during the turn prior to this. For instance, you cannot Royal Decree into Geralt: Igni, or use Precision Strike to set up Scorch in the same turn anymore. Examples: Geralt: Igni, Scorch.

Title: Archetype
Excerpt: The categorization of decks based on either the speed or the play-style at which they function...
Description:
The categorization of decks based on either the speed or the play-style at which they function. The most basic categories include:

  • Aggro
  • Midrange
  • Control
  • Combo

Keep in mind, however, that the Combo archetype is loosely defined in most card games and the line between Midrange, Control and Combo can often be blurry.

Title: Aggro
Excerpt: An archetype of decks that, as the name describes, plays very aggressively with the intent closing out the game during the early stages and before entering late-game...
Description:
An archetype of decks that, as the name describes, plays very aggressively with the intent closing out the game during the early stages and before entering late-game. The mana curve on aggro decks is usually extremely skewed towards the lower extreme (0 - 4 mana) so that they can exploit the fact that they can play the game at a faster pace than their opponents.

Example: The Spider Aggro deck.

Title: Burn (cards)
Description: To draw beyond one's hand size limit of 10.

Title: Burn (spells)
Excerpt: A term that describes spells that are capable of doing direct damage to the enemy Nexus...
Description:
A term that describes spells that are capable of doing direct damage to the enemy Nexus.

Example: Get Excited! , Mystic Shot.

Title: Burn (mana)
Excerpt: If your opponent has 4 or more mana left (including Spell Mana), forcing them into a situation where they cannot utilize their remaining mana in anyway unless they would play into one of your cards would be an attempt at burning their mana...
Description:
If your opponent has 4 or more mana left (including Spell Mana), forcing them into a situation where they cannot utilize their remaining mana in anyway unless they would play into one of your cards would be an attempt at burning their mana.

Example: Suppose you have a Deny card in your hand, if you suspect your opponent has a couple of high-cost spells that they would want to play this turn and you stop playing cards at 4 mana, you're attempting to burn their mana as if they try to play a high cost they would have to play into your Deny.
Variations: Burning mana, burned mana, burn mana, burn, burning, burned, burns mana, burns

Title: Burst (damage)
Excerpt: High amounts of direct Nexus damage through spells...
Description:
High amounts of direct Nexus damage usually through spells.

 Example: Decimate, Mystic Shot and Get Excited! when you have a Leveled up Ezreal and/or Karma.

Title: Champless
Description: A term that describes decks that do not play any champion cards.

Title: Control
Excerpt: An archetype of decks that aims to win through shutting down the opposing board repeatedly and stalling until they can play their high cost win conditions...
Description:
An archetype of decks that aims to win through shutting down the opposing board repeatedly and stalling until they can play their high-cost win conditions.

Example: Corina SI Control, Spooky Karma.

Title: Combo
Excerpt: An archetype of decks that attempts to stall the game until they have all of their combo pieces fully developed, at which point they attempt to burst the opponent down, preferably in one turn...
Description:
An archetype of decks that attempts to stall the game until they have all of their combo pieces fully developed, at which point they attempt to burst the opponent down, preferably in one turn. Very close to Control gameplay-wise but different in terms of win conditions.

Examples: Nox Ezreal, Karma Ezreal. Both decks need to stall until either Ezreal or Karma are leveled up, at which point an attempt will be made to destroy the opponent's Nexus from the burst damage provided by Ezreal and/or Karma.

Title: Cycle
Excerpt: Drawing cards from your deck...
Description:
Drawing cards from your deck.

Example: Playing Rummage to cycle the deck.

Title: Cycle (Draw) Engine
Excerpt: A card whose primary function is drawing more cards from your decks...
Description:
A card whose primary function is drawing more cards from your decks.

Example: Trifarian Assessor is a cycle engine in her respective deck as it can draw up 6 cards from your deck.

Title: Combat Tricks
Excerpt: The ability for either player to respond to the board state during combat phase using certain cards...
Description:
Spells that influence the outcome of combat.

Example: Single Combat, Riposte, Judgement, Harsh Winds.

Title: Chump Block
Excerpt: The ability to block an attack with usually small and cheap followers just for the sake of mitigating the damage rather than trading...
Description:
The ability to block an attack with usually small and cheap followers just for the sake of mitigating the damage rather than trading.

Example: Jury Rig summons and excellent chump blocker.
Variations: Chump blocking, chump blocked, chump blocks, chump blocker, chump blockers

Title: Package
Excerpt: A card package is a group of cards that serve the same purpose in order to facilitate the execution of your ultimate game plan...
Description:
A card package is a group of cards that serve the same purpose in order to facilitate the execution of your ultimate game plan.

Example: The spider package/core/shell in Corina SI helps you survive the early game so that you can more seamlessly enter the later stages of the game where your deck shines.

Title: Engine
Excerpt: Any card that gains value over time...
Description:
Any card that gains value over time.

Example: Karma before she's leveled up. Ezreal. Ashe. Yasuo. Boomcrew Rookie.

Title: Early game
Description: Refers to the early stages of a game, usually rounds 1 through 4.

Title: Flex Spot
Description: A flex spot in a deck is a card or a set of cards that can be replaced with your more preferable choices without hurting the game plan of the deck.

Title: Face
Excerpt: (of any source of damage or healing) to either Nexuses...
Description:
(of any source of damage or healing) to either Nexuses, directly with no regard to the board state.

Example: Going Face with Mystic Shot would mean using that spell to target the enemy Nexus. Face damage would be the amount of damage either Nexus is taking or is going to take.

Title: Flip
Excerpt: (of champions) Level up...
Description:
(of champions) Level up.

Example: Karma flips when you're Enlightened.

Title: Greedy
Description: A term that refers to decks that usually rely on the alignment of far too many stars (!) to work. Otherwise, it can refer to decks with heavy top ends.

Title: Hard-mulligan
Excerpt: To redraw every card in your opening hand that isn't a certain target card in order to have the best chances at drawing that target card...
Description:
To redraw every card in your opening hand that isn't a certain target card in order to have the best chances at drawing that target card.

Example: To hard-mulligan for Zed means kicking every card in your opening hand that isn't Zed.
Variations: Hard mulligan, hard mulliganned, hard mulliganed, hard mulliganning, hard mulliganing, hard mull, hard-mull

Title: Lethal
Excerpt: To have/threaten lethal, is to have enough damage output to destroy the enemy Nexus in one attack phase...
Description:
To have/threaten lethal, is to have enough damage output to destroy the enemy Nexus in one attack phase. 

Example: If you have two copies of Mystic Shot in your hand and your opponent's Nexus is at 4 health, you are threatening lethal. If your opponent doesn't have an answer to lethal threat, you have lethal.

Title: Late game
Description: A term that refers to the later stages of the game, usually from round 8 onward.

Title: Mono
Excerpt: Containing very few or no cards from a second faction...
Description:
Containing very few or no cards from a second region.

Example: Mono Demacia.

Title: Meta
Excerpt: A term that describes something that is effective or prevalent at the time...
Description:
A term that describes something that is effective or prevalent at the time.

Example: A meta deck, a meta card.

Title: Midrange
Excerpt: An archetype of decks that fights for uncontested board presence through forcing favorable trades and playing high tempo cards...
Description:
An archetype of decks that fights for uncontested board presence through forcing favorable trades and playing high tempo cards. 

Example: Midrange Bannermen, also known as Mono Demacia.

Title: Mulligan
Description: Redrawing cards in your opening hand at the start of the game.

Title: Mid game
Description: The transition stage from early game to late game. Usually from rounds 4-5 to 8-9.

Title: Open Attack
Description: Immediately entering combat phase at the start of a round without taking any action except for casting burst spells.

Title: Open Pass
Description: Passing at the start of a round without taking any action.

Title: Out
Excerpt: A way of getting out of an unfavorable situation...
Description:
A way of getting out of an unfavorable situation.

Example: Looking for outs by cycling the deck.

Title: Removal
Excerpt: Any card that is capable of destroying or nullifying a threatening enemy...
Description:
Any card that is capable of destroying or nullifying a threatening enemy.

Example: Thermogenic Beam, Get Excited! , Grasp of the Undying, Vengeance, The Ruination.

Title: Ramp
Excerpt: Originally a term from Magic: the Gathering, refers to purposefully increasing the amount of mana available to you, above the one that is generated every round automatically...
Description:
Originally a term from Magic: the Gathering, refers to purposefully increasing the amount of mana available to you, above the one that is generated every round automatically.

Example: Catalyst of Aeons, Wyrding Stones.

Title: Splash
Excerpt: Adding a few cards from a second region to a deck in order to help cover its weaknesses or empower its strengths...
Description:
Adding a few cards from a second region to a deck in order to help cover its weaknesses or empower its strengths.

Example: Mono Demacia with Deny splash, is stronger versus the control matchup. Elusives can splash Freljord in order to have stronger Elusive units.

Title: Stabilize
Excerpt: To come back from a seemingly overwhelmed position in the game...
Description:
To come back from a seemingly overwhelmed position in the game. 

Example: If your opponent has a full board of high attack followers and champions, The Ruination can help you stabilize.

Title: Synergy
Excerpt: How well two (or more) cards work together in cohesion. A deck is generally considered good if it contains good synergy between its cards...
Description:
How well two (or more) cards work together in cohesion. A deck is generally considered good if it contains good synergy between its cards.

Example: Jeweled Protector synergizes very well with Zed.

Title: SMOrc
Description: To go face.
Variations: Smorcing, smorking, smorcs, smorks, smorced, smorked

Title: Tap (Out/Under)
Excerpt: To tap out, is to have used all of one's mana. To tap under a certain card is to have used up enough mana that you do not have enough mana remaining to play that card anymore...
Description:
To tap out, is to have used all of one's mana. To tap under a certain card is to have used up enough mana that you do not have enough mana remaining to play that card anymore.

Example: To tap under Deny is to have 3 or less remaining mana so that you cannot play Deny in response to a Fast or Slow spell anymore.
Variations: Tapping out, tapping under, tapped out, tapped under, taps out, taps under

Title: Tech
Excerpt: Inclusion of a card whose sole purpose is countering a popular strategy. Very close in meaning to splash...
Description:
Inclusion of a card whose sole purpose is countering a popular strategy. Very close in meaning to splash.

Example: Teching Deny for the control matchup.

Title: Trade
Excerpt: Giving up a card for another card. During combat or otherwise...
Description:
Giving up a card for another card. During combat or otherwise.

Example: Trading The Ruination for Deny. Trading a 2/1 for a 3/2.

Title: Tempo
Excerpt: The value of the effect on the board state divided by the mana used. Otherwise can refer to the momentum of a game...
Description:
The value of the effect on the board state divided by the mana used. Otherwise can refer to the momentum of a game.

Example: A high-tempo card/play. A tempo deck.

Title: Win condition
Excerpt: How a deck aims to win. Refers either to a strategy or a set of cards...
Description:
How a deck aims to win. Refers either to a strategy or a set of cards.

Example: Corina Verassa and Commander Ledros can be regarded as Corina SI control's win conditions. A leveled up Karma and/or Ezreal is the Karma Ezreal Combo deck's win condition.

Title: Whiff
Excerpt: To fail a random check with (usually) very low chances of failure...
Description:
To fail a random check with (usually) very low chances of failure.

Example: Whiffing the Kinkou Pathfinder would mean that you didn't get the bonus from that card's Allegiance ability even though the chances were very high.

Title: Float
Excerpt: (usually of an order ability) to not use until a more opportune time...
Description:
(usually of an order ability) to not use until a more opportune time.

Example: Floating the order on Maraal would mean not using his order ability in order, for instance, to threaten immediately destroying an opposing threat by poisoning once from hand and a second time using the floated charge on Maraal.

Title: Chip damage
Description: Originally a term from fighting games that refers to the damage you take while blocking, here it means dealing face damage in small doses to slowly "chip" away at your opponent's nexus.

Title: Matchup
Excerpt: How well a deck performs against another one...
Description:
How well a deck performs against another one.

Example: The ‘X’ matchup for the deck ‘Y’ is pretty favorable.

Title: SI
Description: Short for "Shadow Isles".

Description: Refers to the act of playing non-committally (usually in the form of an inexpensive card) to pass the action back to your opponent, effectively waiting on their play.
